docs.lead_paragraph: Since a heart attack in 1989, Len Quesnelle has had a dozen tests to study the blocked arteries of his heart, spent weeks in intensive care because of chest pain and finally, in March, had a triple bypass. He has seen his share of doctors and hospitals, but he has never received a bill, paid a health insurance premium or filled out a health insurance form. Although the price for his recent surgery, calculated in American dollars, was $14,000, he paid less than $200, for telephone calls and renting a television. Comprehensive Health Insurance As a citizen of Canada, Mr. Quesnelle is a beneficiary of one of the world's most comprehensive health insurance programs, the Canadian national health plan, which uses tax money to provide medical care to everyone at no charge.

headline.main: Canada's National Health Plan Gives Care to All, With Limits

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As Jane Brody's Personal Health Column on springtime nasal allergy (April 11) rightly states, inhaled pollens cause an inflammatory reaction in the nose. Antihistamines in general do not treat the basic reaction of inflammation. They merely relieve some symptoms (sneezing, itching and runny nose) caused by the allergic reaction. They do not relieve symptoms of congestion, which require a second drug, a decongestant. Ms. Brody suggests there can be immunity to antihistamines. This has never been proved.

headline.main: What to Do About Springtime Sneezing
